metadata.title: Synthesis, characterization and use of iron oxide nano particles for antibacterial activity

sections.text:
University, Islamabad, Pakistan 2Mohi-ud-din Islamic University, Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Pakistan 3State Key Laboratory of Systematic and Evolutionary Botany, Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China 4University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China 5CAS Key Laboratory of Mountain Ecological Restoration and Bioresource Utilization, Chengdu Institute of Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Chengdu, China 6Department of Chemistry, Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Science (PIEAS), Islamabad, Pakistan
Correspondence Fazal Ullah and Wajid Zaman, Department of Plant Sciences, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad 45320, Pakistan. Emails: fazalbotanist@gmail.com; shangla123@gmail.com
Review Editor: Paul Verkade
due to remarkable alternative properties compared to molecular antibiotics. Thus, the use of iron oxide nanoparticles (IONPs) has proven one of the most important transition metals oxidebased remedy in nanotechnological advances and biological applications due to enriched biocompatibility of iron. In this study synthesis of IONPs was carried out via co-precipitation method. The crystallographic morphology of the synthesized particles was studied via X-ray diffraction which revealed cubic structure of the particles, whereas, the spinal shaped morphology of the prepared NPs was confirmed from scanning electron microscopy. Likewise, the presence of the major elements in the sample was determined through energy dispersive X-ray analysis characterization. Bactericidal effect of the NPs was assessed at pre-defined concentrations (50 and 100 μg/ml) against Gram +ve bacteria Staphylococcus aureus, Gram −ve bacteria Shigella dysentry and Escherichia coli. Bacterial strains, which demonstrate the potential of NPs. The purpose of this study was assessing the structure of the synthesized NPs for protective effect against harmful bacterial activity.
KEYWORDS
bacteria, co-precipitation, iron oxide, nanoparticles, SEM

sections.heading: 1 | INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
The prevalence of antibiotic resistance and multi drug resistant strains Gram +ve and Gram −ve microbes are serious threat to global
population. Such resistance is due to indiscriminate use of antibiotics
favoring evolution of novel antibiotic resistance strain at faster pace
(Raghunath & Perumal, 2017). World health organization (WHO)
highlighted one of the most common cause of death in the world is
microbial contamination and pathogens resistance to drugs (Shinwari,
Ahmad, Luo, & Zaman, 2017; Sportelli, Picca, & Cioffi, 2016). Therefore,
synthesis of new and effective antimicrobial agents seems to be of
greater importance. Recent advances in the field of nanotechnology
bolster the ability to prepare metal oxide nano particles (NPs) of specific
size and shape which contribute to the development of new antibacter-
ial agents (Azam et al., 2012; Saqib et al. 2017). Advantage of nanoma-
terials over traditional antibiotics is due to their surface area and
chemical reactivity are exceedingly large as compared to bulk materials (Wang, Hu, & Shao, 2017). Therefore, iron oxide nanoparticles (IONPs)
is attracting much attention in the field of biomedicines either as
contrast agents for magnetic resonance imaging (Pouponneau, Leroux, Soulez, Gaboury, & Martel, 2011), heating mediators for hyperthermia
(Lee et al., 2011), drug/gene delivery carriers (Subramanian, Abimanyu,
Vinoth, & Sekar, 2010) and antimicrobial agents (Azam et al., 2012).
NPs have shown broad-spectrum antibacterial activities against Gram +ve and Gram −ve bacteria because metal NPs have the ability
to change the metabolic activity of bacteria (Chatzimitakos & Stalikas,
2016). This capability enhance the capacity to cure diseases by targeting bacteria such as, bactericidal effect of ZnO NPs against Staphylococ-
cus aureus and Ag NPs inhibits Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas
aeruginosa (Ramalingam, Parandhaman, & Das, 2016). The physical properties of nanomaterials including size, charge, zeta potential,
surface morphology, and crystal structure control their action on
Microsc Res Tech. 2018;1–6. wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/jemt © 2018 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. 1
bacterial cells (Wang et al., 2017). Therefore NPs has potential to disrupt biofilms and become promising material against microbes (Zhao & Ashraf, 2015). The antimicrobial mechanisms of NPs involve three model oxidative stress induction, metal ion release, or non-oxidative mechanism. The advantage of the NPs is that these three mechanisms can occur simultaneously (Wang et al., 2017). Subsequently, NPs damage the basic components of the bacterial cell such as DNA, lysosomes, ribosomes, enzyme inhibition, proteins deactivation, changes in cell membrane permeability, and changes in genes expression that ultimately leads to cell death (Xu et al., 2016). So, there is dire need to focus on biocompatible NP-based material with antibacterial activity.
Antimicrobial activity of IONPs is of great importance due to controlled size, high magnetism and low toxicity (Azam et al., 2012; Kai, Xiaojun, Ximing, Zhenqing, & Qiqing, 2011). Due to difference in the cell walls of Gram +ve and Gram −ve the action of NPs dependent on bacterial strains (Tran et al., 2010). The mechanism involves electrostatic interaction between bacterial cell wall and NPs which deteriorate cell wall of bacteria and induces toxic oxidative stress by producing reactive oxygen species (ROS; Ahmad, Farrukh, Khan, Khaleeq-ur-Rahman, & Tahir, 2014). The bactericidal effects of IONPs provide high bioactivity even if small dose is used. Contrarily, the action of antibiotics attacks three bacterial sites that is, Cell wall, translational machinery and DNA replication, due to this reason bacterial resistance develop against each one of these modes of actions (Woolhouse, Ward, van Bunnik, & Farrar, 2015). The mechanism of resistance comprise expression of enzymes that degrade antibiotics such as β lactamases and aminoglycosides (Poole, 2002). The mode of action of NPs develop a direct contact with the bacterial cell wall that damage the bacterial cell without penetration to the cell. Therefore, NPs are less prone to bacterial resistance than antibiotics (Wang et al., 2017). Biocompatibility and magnetic properties of IONPs make it promising material against every type of pathogens (Li, Chen, & Gu, 2012). In addition, positive surface charge of the metal NPs promote their binding to the negatively charge surface of bacteria which enhance antimicrobial activity of IONPs (Seil & Webster, 2012). Furthermore the size of the NPs influence bactericidal activity of the NPs (Besinis, De Peralta, & Handy, 2014; Fellahi et al., 2013). Hence there lies a great challenge to examine the surface and size of the synthesized NPs to restrict microbial growth.
The aim of the present study is to assess morphology and size of the prepared IONPs via X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscope (SEM). Moreover, antibacterial behavior of the synthesized IONPs have been studied. Although, various studies have been conducted to evaluate the antibacterial activity of IONPs toward some selective bacteria, nevertheless, the bacterial inhibition comparison of IONPs against Gram +ve and Gram −ve bacteria has not been explored in detail.

sections.heading: 2.1 | Reagents
sections.text: Ferrous chloride tetrahydrate (FeCl2.4H2O), ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3.6H2O), and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 0.2 M) along with distilled water were used in the synthesis of nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.2 | Synthesis of IONPs
sections.text: Iron oxide NPs were prepared based on the co-precipitation method by following a published research (Kaushik et al., 2008) with a slight modification. To proceed the reaction, aqueous solutions of ferrous chloride tetrahydrate (FeCl2.4H2O, 10 ml) and ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3.6H2O, 20 ml) were thoroughly mixed in a 100 ml beaker using magnetic stirrer at 500 rpm at room temperature to obtain a clear solution of pH 4. Simultaneously, 10 ml solution of 0.2 M hydrochloric acid (HCl) was added dropwise into the stirring solution for about 4 hr until the precipitate was obtained. The precipitate was centrifuged at 8000 rpm for 15 min to remove the unreacted watersoluble ions by discarding the supernatant. The obtained material was washed several times with distilled water and finally with methanol. The prepared NPs were dried in a vacuum oven at 40 C for 4 hr and kept in a closed container for further use.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 | X-ray diffraction
sections.text: To analyze structure of the newly synthesized IONPs XRD was employed. The XRD pattern of IONPs were recorded on X-ray diffractometer at the range of 2θ from 10 to 80 with a scan rate of 20 / min using Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 A ) radiation with an accelerating voltage of 40 KV. Different phases present in the samples were evaluated via X0-pert high score software having search and match facility.

sections.heading: 2.3.2 | Scanning electron microscopy
sections.text: The scanning electron microscopy was carried out to study the surface morphology of IONPs. The nanoparticles were taken and mounted with double adhesive tape on stubs, sputter coated with gold palladium and were studied under SEM installed at central resources library University of Peshawar. To analyze morphological features of IONPs field emission scanning electron microscope was used at an accelerating voltage of 10 KV upon gold coating for 4 min. SEM modal JEOL JSM-5910 were used and the picture were taken with Polaroid P/N 665 film.

sections.heading: 2.3.3 | Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy analysis
sections.text: Energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDS) attached with SEM determined presence of different elements in the NPs sample. The specimen was determined through EDS software that applies ZAF correction and carries out subsequent integration of the peaks to get the final quantification of the elements present in the sample.

sections.heading: 2.4 | Antibacterial activity of IONPs NPs
sections.text:
To assess the antibacterial activity of the synthesized NPs different strains of bacteria Gram +ve S. aureus and Gram −ve E. coli, and S. dysentery were checked by using well diffusion method (Wikler, 2009). In short dried IONPs of 50 μg/ml were weighed and dissolved in distilled water. The inoculums of selected strains (S. aureus, E. coli, and S. dysentery) were prepared by growing a single colony for 24 hr in nutrient broth. The prepared nutrient broth agar plates were swabbed with bacterial strains broth. Furthermore, 20 μl of synthesized IONPs
50 μg/ml was added in wells. The samples treated plates were incubated at 37 C for 48 hr and the zone of inhibition was measured. The experimental data was collected from three independent experiments and the averages was reported.

sections.heading: 3.1 | Synthesis mechanism of iron oxide nanoparticles
sections.text:
In the present study, the particles prepared via co-precipitation method were in red brick colors (Figure 1) which is the characteristic color of IONPs. The main advantage of the co-precipitation method was that large number of particles can be synthesized with expense of lowest cost and minimum pollution (Petcharoen & Sirivat, 2012).
The synthesis of IONPs is a multifaceted task because of their colloidal nature. The core challenges in synthesis process include delineating reaction conditions which play role in procurement of suitable size metal particles (Laurent et al., 2008). Another critical condition is to adopt a reproducible process which can be easily industrialized without any complex purification method such as, ultracentrifugation (Sjögren et al., 1997), magnetic filtration (Babes, Denizot, Tanguy, Le Jeune, & Jallet, 1999), flow field gradient (Thurm & Odenbach, 2002), and coprecipitation method (Martínez-Mera, Espinosa-Pesqueira, Pérez-Hernández, & Arenas-Alatorre, 2007; Morrison, Cahill, Carpenter, Calvin, & Harris, 2005). These methods are commonly used to obtain particles of narrow size distribution and homogenous mixture. Furthermore, this method has the potential to encounter the increasing demand of direct synthesis of well dispersed (water base) IONPs for engineering and biomedical applications (Kulkarni & Muddapur, 2014).

sections.heading: 3.2 | XRD analysis
sections.text:
The XRD alignment of IONPs expressed peaks at 2θ 24.122, 33.185, 35.625, 49.423, 54.026, and 63.942 were analogous to peak values of
(110), (114), (024), (214), (280), and (268) planes of rhombohedral IONPs (Figure 2). The peaks were in consistent with the database in JCPDS file no. 77–1545. The diffraction peaks also proved that the synthesized IONPs were pure with crystalline nature. The average particle size calculated with Scherrer's formula was found to be 38 nm. The obtained XRD data in this study was well matched with XRD spectra shown in previous literature (Arokiyaraj et al., 2013; Oskam, 2006; Song, Lee, Jo, Nam, & Kang, 2012). The XRD pattern revealed crystalline nature of the NPs which efficiently regulate the action of NPs on bacterial cell walls (Wang et al., 2017). Furthermore, the crystalline particles can prevent biofilms formation and inducing oxidative stress which is important antibacterial mechanism of NPs (Malka et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 3.3 | Scanning electron microscopy
3.4 | Energy dispersive X-ray analysis
sections.text: The composition of the product was further confirmed by EDS. EDS spectrum revealed strong peak of iron in the range of 6.0–8.0 keV (Figure 4). The presence of oxygen also indicated at the range from 1.0 to 2.0 keV. The obtained results manifest total 38.08 wt % of elemental oxygen and 61.92% iron. Similar results are also reported in literature (Hua & Gengsheng, 2009; Teng & Yang, 2003). So, presence of iron in higher percentage in the sample can cause bacterial cell decomposition (Sultana, Das, Bhattacharya, Basu, & Nandy, 2012).

sections.heading: 3.5 | Antibacterial assay
sections.text: Antibacterial activity of the IONPs examined against bacterial strains E. coli, S. dysentery, and S. aureus (Table 1). The study revealed that average inhibition against E. coli was 12.95, S. dysentery 12.63, and S. aureus 13.21. The observations reported that very minimum amount of activity against the tested bacterial strains was reported. Our results are comparable with the results reported by Tran et al. (2010). The bactericidal effect of the IONPs is due to its small particle size (Lee et al., 2008) which is confirmed through SEM in our result. The mechanism involve interaction of IONPs with bacterial cell wall, deactivating cellular enzymes, causing disruption in plasma membrane permeability. The disturbance in plasma membrane release ROS that can damage the DNA and proteins which eventually leads to cell death (Kohanski, DePristo, & Collins, 2010). In addition, metal ions after absorption through cell membrane interact with the functional groups of proteins and nucleic acid such as mercapto (–SH), amino (–NH), and carboxyl (–COOH) groups damaging enzyme activity and physiological processes which ultimately inhibit bacterial growth (Yu et al., 2014). Guittat et al. (2003) reported that small particle size cause inhibition of DNA synthesis in bacteria through damage to topoisomerase. So, the inhibitory effect of the IONP is due to small particle size proved by SEM and XRD.

sections.heading: 4 | CONCLUSION
sections.text:
The present study proposed an efficient and cost-effective protocol for the synthesis of smaller size IONPs. Study of the prepared IONPs through SEM and XRD confirmed the particle size for possible destructive interaction towards bacterial cell wall. This study will open new ways of applying NPs in biomedical and drug delivery applications in future. Iron is a biocompatible metal, so it can be used directly against many types of pathogens such as, human pathogens and phytopathogens. This study also concludes the significance of SEM in deriving the particle size to use for further applications. Moreover, the field need to research on other aspects which will help to elucidate NPs synthesis in drug discoveries.

The XRD pattern revealed crystalline nature of the NPs which efficiently regulate the action of NPs on bacterial cell walls (Wang et al., 2017).
Furthermore, the crystalline particles can prevent biofilms formation and inducing oxidative stress which is important antibacterial mechanism of NPs (Malka et al., 2013).
Agglomeration can be seen in the SEM images of the subject particles which might be due to electrostatic interaction between layers of NPs surface (Song et al., 2012).
The shape of NPs play a basic role in producing pathways for the adsorption of NPs (Lesniak et al., 2013) that eventually cause cell death.
SEM played a key role to explore the size and morphology of the NPs because the biological behavior of the NPs strongly depends on size and shape (Laurent et al., 2008).
The bactericidal effect of the IONPs is due to its small particle size (Lee et al., 2008) which is confirmed through SEM in our result.

In addition, metal ions after absorption through cell membrane interact with the functional groups of proteins and nucleic acid such as mercapto (–SH), amino (–NH), and carboxyl (–COOH) groups damaging enzyme activity and physiological processes which ultimately inhibit bacterial growth (Yu et al., 2014).

metadata.abstractText: Department of Plant Sciences, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan Mohi-ud-din Islamic University, Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Pakistan State Key Laboratory of Systematic and Evolutionary Botany, Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China CAS Key Laboratory of Mountain Ecological Restoration and Bioresource Utilization, Chengdu Institute of Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Chengdu, China Department of Chemistry, Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Science (PIEAS), Islamabad, Pakistan Correspondence Fazal Ullah and Wajid Zaman, Department of Plant Sciences, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad 45320, Pakistan. Emails: fazalbotanist@gmail.com; shangla123@gmail.com Review Editor: Paul Verkade Abstract In this decade, the use of nano particles (NPs) against bacterial growth is increasing day by day due to remarkable alternative properties compared to molecular antibiotics. Thus, the use of iron oxide nanoparticles (IONPs) has proven one of the most important transition metals oxidebased remedy in nanotechnological advances and biological applications due to enriched biocompatibility of iron. In this study synthesis of IONPs was carried out via co-precipitation method. The crystallographic morphology of the synthesized particles was studied via X-ray diffraction which revealed cubic structure of the particles, whereas, the spinal shaped morphology of the prepared NPs was confirmed from scanning electron microscopy. Likewise, the presence of the major elements in the sample was determined through energy dispersive X-ray analysis characterization. Bactericidal effect of the NPs was assessed at pre-defined concentrations (50 and 100 μg/ml) against Gram +ve bacteria Staphylococcus aureus, Gram −ve bacteria Shigella dysentry and Escherichia coli. Bacterial strains, which demonstrate the potential of NPs. The purpose of this study was assessing the structure of the synthesized NPs for protective effect against harmful bacterial activity.
